content: The Identity Theft and Assumption Deterrence Act of 1998 is cited as the constitutional authority to regulate commerce and make laws necessary for executing government powers. The Identity Theft and Assumption Deterrence Act of 1998 amends Section 1028 of title 18, United States Code to include penalties for knowingly transferring or using another person's identification without lawful authority for unlawful activities. The Identity Theft and Assumption Deterrence Act of 1998 amends penalties for identity theft under Section 1028 of title 18, United States Code, including fines and imprisonment for offenses involving the transfer or use of identification documents or means of identification to obtain anything of value aggregating $1,000 or more in a year. The Identity Theft and Assumption Deterrence Act of 1998 enhances penalties for identity theft under Section 1028 of title 18, United States Code. This includes forfeiture of personal property used in committing the offense and specifies that the prohibited actions must affect interstate or foreign commerce. The Identity Theft and Assumption Deterrence Act of 1998 increases penalties for identity theft under Section 1028 of title 18, United States Code, involving interstate or foreign commerce. It includes forfeiture of property used in the offense and defines terms like "document-making implement" and "identification document." The term "means of identification" refers to any name or number that can be used to identify an individual, including personal information like names, social security numbers, biometric data, electronic identification numbers, and telecommunication identifying information. Section 105(b) of the Ethics in Government Act of 1978 is amended to allow for redaction of reports filed by individuals if revealing personal information could endanger them. The Judicial Conference, in consultation with the United States Marshall Service, can make this determination. The amended Section 105(b) of the Ethics in Government Act of 1978 allows for redaction of reports to protect individuals from potential threats. The Judicial Conference, in consultation with the Department of Justice, will issue regulations on when redaction is appropriate and the procedures for it.
